ACT
199
Inheritance insurance. Handing over for safekeeping
If it is established that none of the heirs present is capable of managing the estate or anything from its composition, and there is no legal representative, or if the heirs are unknown or absent, or when other circumstances require special caution, a police officer or another person managing on behalf the authorities will, in emergency cases, hand over these things to the safekeeping of a reliable person and immediately inform the court in whose territory these things are located, which can amend or cancel this measure.
Cash, securities, valuables, savings books and other important documents, in the case referred to in paragraph 1 of this article, should be handed over for safekeeping to the court or notary public in whose territory the property is located.
Whoever receives for safekeeping the items referred to in paragraphs 1 and 2 of this article, is obliged to issue a certificate to that effect, which will be handed over to the court in whose territory those items are located by the person who deposited them.
The court referred to in paragraphs 1 and 2 of this article shall notify the probate court of all measures taken to secure the estate.
